thread.title: CORONA: Worker injured in 91 freeway project mishap fighting for life, fiancee says
thread.title_full: CORONA: Worker injured in 91 freeway project mishap fighting for life, fiancee says - Press Enterprise

author: PATRICK ONEILL
title: CORONA: Worker injured in 91 freeway project mishap fighting for life, fiancee says
text:
By PATRICK ONEILL / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 12, 2015 Updated: 10:03 p.m. CORONA: Worker injured in 91 freeway project mishap fighting for life, fiancee says Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 3 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT A construction worker arranges safety cones near a partially collapsed bridge on the 91 freeway in Corona on Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015. ALI TADAYON, STAFF Related article » HOW TO HELP Want to help Kendra Santos and her family?
Go to www.gofundme.com/yt65ewtg
One of the nine workers injured Friday, Oct. 9, when a section of the 91 freeway on-ramp under construction above East Grand Boulevard in Corona dropped unexpectedly by more than a foot and snapped wooden support beams is fighting for his life, his fiancee said Monday, Oct. 12.
Jarrell Boyd, a 33-year-old Riverside native, may not survive injuries suffered when he was struck by the falling beams, fiancee Kendra Santos said. His shoulder, neck and femur are broken, and doctors have drilled a hole in his skull to monitor swelling, she said.
“The neurosurgeon came in and said there’s a possibility he may not make it,” Santos said.
Seven workers remained hospitalized Monday night, said John Standiford, deputy director of the Riverside County Transportation Commission. No update has been given on the condition of three men who were initially reported in critical condition.
All construction has been halted on the $1.4 billion 91 freeway expansion project following Friday night’s accident – save the erection of a safety fence at the affected site – while state transportation officials investigate the mishap.
Story continues below. Mobile users, click here to see a graphic explaining the bridge collapse.
Work was expected to resume early Tuesday morning, but the bridge-lowering procedure used Friday will be banned until the state’s investigation is complete, Standiford said.
The on-ramp over East Grand Boulevard had to be built about 16 inches higher than its intended placement so traffic could flow beneath it during construction. The road has since been lowered to accommodate the final placement of the expanded on-ramp. During the procedure used Friday, the plan was to slowly lower the 118-foot, 750-ton slab into position. Instead, the slab fell into the wooden support beams and snapped them.
Atkinson Walsh, contractors for the project, successfully completed another 91 bridge using the same method, Standiford said. This approach had been planned for three more bridges, but that is being re-evaluated.
Spokespersons at Atkinson Walsh did not respond to repeated inquiries about the incident.
Caltrans and OSHA are investigating, as well as an independent company hired by the contractors. There was no estimate on how long the process could take.
“At this point, we’ll take whatever time is necessary to learn what we need from what happened,” Standiford said of the three-day setback. “Safety is way too important to cut corners.”
Roughly 500 construction workers have logged more than a million hours of labor on the project so far, Standiford said. Prior to Friday’s incident, five people had been injured, and only one of those required time off from work.
On Monday, a pair of construction workers leaned against a concrete barrier along East Grand Boulevard, urging drivers to slow down while passing under the freeway. Several men in hard hats and high-visibility vests took measurements at the base of the newly-installed Main Street on-ramp. RCTC officials say the ramp is undamaged and placed in the proper position.
For now, Santos said, all she can do is wait and hope for the father of her 7-year-old son to wake up. She doesn’t place the blame on anyone in particular for what happened, but said she hopes that lessons are being learned.
“I feel like what (construction crews) do is already so dangerous,” Santos said. “The safety of their employees should always be their top priority.”
Contact the writer: 951-368-9644, poneill@pe.com , @PE_PatrickO
